The fragrance bears a striking resemblance to Lalique Equus, radiating an alluring blend of animalic notes and warm spices that evoke a sense of rich, primal energy. Both scents share a comparable profile and feature similar ingredients, creating an olfactory experience that intertwines warmth and complexity. However, while Lalique Equus draws inspiration from the majestic horse, this alternative invokes the spirited essence of a zebra, adding a unique twist to the scent narrative.

Glasgow airport, 1998. A woman was promoting this in the duty free section, so I took a spray, then bought 2 bottles straight away. For me, this is one of the holy trinity of my youth. The other 2 being Gph 1 & Envy. And i'm fortunate enough to own all of them today.

What can this compare to.... nothing really. It stands apart from anything else I've ever tried. Longevity isn't great, but so what. This one is the old mate you've known for decades who visits you every so often for a couple of hours, we've all moved on and have families and busy lives now, to reminisce about the old days. And when he leaves, you're glad he dropped by, because you're always left in a really good mood.

I own multiple back up bottles of this that I'll never get through. But that's ok, knowing they are there is good enough for me.
Very close to bentley for men absolute. Amazing dry woody scent!

I just picked up Kenzo Jungle Homme for a steal, and I'm thoroughly impressed so far.

Judging by the reviews I wasn't quite sure how animalic, cumin-spicy, sweet, or generally weird this would be. I'm here to report that, at least based on a freshly opened bottle, this is very smooth, well-blended and balanced.

Mentions of a discongruous, disgusting opening do not align with my experience. The refreshing citrus and spices mingle immediately with warm and woody base notes and does not come off as super challenging or helter skelter. Yes, there is cumin, accounting for the BO complaints, but it's brief and enjoyable and is mostly gone by the time the heart arrives within 30min. Do you like cumin? Great. Are you super sensitive to absolutely any amount? Avoid this, but for those in the middle know that it's not overbearing and blends in with the rest of the notes quickly.

There is some cinnamon and nutmeg, adding a spice melange texture that plays nicely into the woods and mellow benzoin sweetness. I detest any syrupy, overdosed sweetness, and Jungle provides sweetness in a balanced form that plays into the naturally sweet qualities of cinnamon, nutmeg, sandalwood and guaiac wood. No cavities here.

Is Jungle a little funky? Yes! But that is part of it's charm, and that subjective funkiness completely melts away quickly into a very pleasant and silky experience for lovers of wood and spice. Time will tell on performance, but first impressions are that after the first 30min this sits closer to the skin, with middle of the road projection.

What I really love about Jungle is the subtlety in how the woody base is rendered. It's softer, subtle, and allows itself to be discovered, which is directly opposite to the trend of akigalwood, amberwood, and super loud woody aromachemicals found in many woody bases of today.

I am slightly reminded of Costume National Homme, but that is louder in spice, projection and sweetness but shares the nutmeg spice over a warm, sandalwoody base. Azzaro Visit is in the ballpark as well, but that is far muskier, has noticeable vetiver, and the woody notes are far more scratchy and synthetic to my nose. Kenzo Jungle threads the needle of these two for me, and instantly resonates more.

The last comparison is one to Principe Real by Antiga Barbearia de Bairro (a small shaving company I discovered in Portugal) that I highly recommend. Both share fresh citrus openings, spicy and semi-sweet notes, on top of beautiful and subtle woody bases. They are different but similar in general character and both make incredibly versatile scents that span age ranges, seasons, and note profiles. Apparently, Principe Real is extremely similar to Guerlain L'instant Homme, so I would guess fans of Kenzo Jungle could give that a look as well.

Jungle is currently a huge bargain under $50, but I think it transcends the bargain category and is just plain good. Last thing, I think the bottle is ridiculous and fun and very 90s. The zebra mohawk is zany. The cap is kind of tough to get off. But the ergonomics?! They are great. The bottle shape and the textured frosted stripes on the back of the bottle are a textural smorgasbord, and sum up the contents well:

Somewhere between smooth and classy and not taking itself too seriously.
A unique scent, the dry down is a beautiful woody scent (unlike most Middle Eastern). Actually is very good for this season (colder weather).

A unique spin on the woody/spicy category- loaded with spices and wood, but softened and tempered so that there are no sharp or spiky edges. It's soft, sweet, warm, creamy and comforting. The lime in the opening surprises me as a unique and lovely counterpart to the warm spices. The woody side has a soft velvet texture and a wood sap type of sweetness. It has my Goldilocks level of presence- consistently noticeable and enjoyable for the wearer over long hours without screaming or assaulting everyone in the room with harsh or brash aromachems. It's soothing and soft on the senses the whole way down, with the far dry down being such a lovely sandalwood. There is also something that makes me sense the creaminess of a freshly opened gardenia blossom without actually smelling like gardenia- I don't know what's accounting for that sensation but I love that aspect.
Animalic and woody. The animalic part sort of smells like bad breath.

Similarity to issey miyake but unique in its own way. Longevity, spicy and lovely! Had this bottle for many years like my Issey Miyake and smelI has not altered in the slightest. If you do not own it, i recommend you try this
With the first puff you will go to one of the most beautiful forests! The final note is very beautiful and pleasant

Very unique blend, warm and spicy but yet very fresh and woody.
But don't mistaken it for a cold weather fragrance. the downside here, is the performance, the silage is pretty decent , but it only lasts for 3 hours then it skin scent. best worn on a warm summer night.
8.5/10
PS
Beautiful bottle design,With the little zebra mane, looks cool on display
Wow. When you're able to vision what the director amd perfumer was trying to accomplish then that's art. Art in a bottle that's what this is!!!!

Kenzo Jungle Homme is among Olivier Cresp's finest creations. An apotheosis of woods and spice, it shows how spices, especially a radiant cardamom and bittersweet nutmeg complement woods, giving them lift and diffusivity. Opening with a lime and bergamot, these spices are the spine right through to the bass line.

Fresh and tangy transform into a peppery warmth, with what I detect is a sizable amount of guaiac wood, which has a unique, slightly smoky, oleaginous and balsamic feel. It fuses woody notes together in perfume; a fascinating material, it serves as glue to the otherwise elusive facets of sandalwood and cedar. It's like the oil that keeps the warmth in the lamp going.

There is an underlying fresh perspiration feel here, not unlike that of Declaration (no Iso E Super here, however). This imparts a subtle human carnality. The overall effect is balmy and exotic, much like its sibling Kenzo Jungle L'Elephant; however, Homme is modulated to a more simmering volume and is reignited through the heat of one's own body through wear (I love this phenomenon).

My last bottle was a decade ago and this still slaps 😊👌

I can’t get past the body odor scent in the initial blast. I mean, I just took a shower before applying so I knew it wasn’t me.
For better or worse the dry down smells like Indian cuisine.

Kenzo Jungle is a rare find today that exceeds expectation. Definitely deserves the positive rating. Starts with a tart citrus opening but within minutes morphs into a slightly sweet, slightly creamy, light woods fragrance that reminds me of a lighter, more natural, Allure Homme Sport Extreme. The Mate note is there, keeping it from going too sweet. This could easily be a signature scent 9 months out of the year. Amazed at how natural this smells compared to the majority of synthetic fragrances in this price range.

MATERIALS:
Kenzo Jungle Pour Homme, Eau de Toilette
Batch Code: V818806
Box: Maroon with a dark maroon raised zebra pattern that only appears on the upper half of the front of the box. The neon green square on the front feels slightly raised and has maroon print letters on it that read “Kenzo Jungle Pour Homme”. The inside is lined with a removable neon green carton insert. Mine also came with a folded mail-in survey about the fragrance.

Bottle: 1.7oz./5ml. Clear, rectangular, glass spray bottle with matte silver sprayer and cap. The cap is topped with black and white plastic bristles that alternate to imitate a zebra pattern. The face of the bottle says “Kenzo” in dark maroon cursive letters appearing right-of-center at the base. The back of the bottle has a zebra pattern etched on it that mimics the design on the box and the batch code, also etched, appears centered at the base in small print.

PROCEDURE:
Tested on a cool spring day. Low activity level, mostly sitting (working from home):

OBSERVATIONS:
To my (41M) untrained nose…

First spray to 30 minutes: Upon first spray the citrus smell is dominant – a very sharp and tarty lime. This remains so for about 20 to 30 minutes before the woody notes creep in.

Minutes 30 – 40: The woody notes intermingle with the citrus for about ten minutes until the citrus becomes less prominent.

Minutes 40 – 60: The citrus has taken a back seat but has not entirely disappeared. The woody notes are now prominent and seem sweet but not cloying.

Minutes 60 – 70: For a very brief 5 to 10 minutes, the scent becomes sweet almost resembling the smell of bubblegum. Then the spices come in to play.

Minutes 70 – 90: The spices emerge to combine with the sweet, woody notes and the citrus. For a brief couple of minutes, this combination of notes smells like a showered man who is drenched in his fresh sweat has just jogged right past you – don’t let this alarm you, it’s pleasant and it passes quickly, unfortunately. The rest of the scent ride is dominated by soft spice notes that fade into a skin scent.

CONCLUSION:
This is a UNISEX scent all the way, despite the “pour homme.” The ride is short but adventuresome and worth it. On a cool spring day and low activity level, the scent felt private and very quiet. Although further testing is required under different weather conditions and activity levels, its performance indicates it may be appropriate for year-round use for formal, informal, and professional settings.

VERY spicey. Reminds me a lot of the Opihr Oriental Spiced Gin, or Indian restaurants.

There is a lot going on. It's not subtle, very strong, bold, warm. Nice and cosey. It is still fresh even if it is so spicey. More spice than wood. Unisex to me.
Weird opening. Dries down to a generic cologne smell. Nothing to get excited about.

Woody, fresh and slightly tangy.

It is a nice gentleman fragrance, I use it as part of my rotation as professional scent for "non special occasions".

I blind bought it because it was cheap and 2 of my favorite fragrance reviewers recommended it.
It is not bad, nor anything to write home about.

My critique: no note seems to really shine in this fragrance. Imagine an oil painting, now put many colors together and mix it - it will give you a dirty brown color - thats the picture that comes to my mind the first time I smelled this fragrance.

Other fragrances that could be worn in the same situations, with (kind of) similar vibes, but are better in my opinion (either fresher, with more punch, more inviting and/or with more clarity):
- Terre d'Hermes
- Encre Noir
- Narciso Rodrigues Blue Noir
- Guerlain Homme
- Dunhill Icon
- Herrera
jungle homme was one of the first perfumes i owned in my youth. it screamed "rise and grind" to me, due to its very animalistic and spicy opening.

Initially juicy lime, creamy guaiac wood, non-stinky nutmeg and cardamom, and a hint of cinnamon and maté, which is a freshly warm blend that oddly resembles cakes with sweet jam; then it evolves to mostly guaiac wood, sandalwood and amber, which is sweet and rather creamy. After 0.5h or so the strange chemistry on my skin imparts this pleasant juice with metallic notes T.T

It's a peculiar (or unique) cologne that's like no other. Unlike the many bottled diabetes for men nowadays that are a dime a dozen, this jungle homme is particularly interesting.

Intimate projection and below average longevity.

Unfortunately, it's discontinued. It's purported to have been resumed in a hideous bottle.

To me it smells like sawdust in a woodshop, and I'm here for it! I love Azzarro Visit as well, and kinda get the comparison, but to my nose that one has more vetiver, and this one is more centered on the wood. I don't find them redundant at all. If you don't want to smell like sawdust, I'd pass, but this is an absolute love for me and takes me back to hanging out with my grandpa in his woodshop. Love it, love it, love it!

This is a divine scent! This scent is beautiful! I get a lot of cinnamon and nutmeg initially with a nice vanilla and benzoin under side. When you smell this you'll be glad you got it! This is an easy blind buy if you think that it's a type of fragrance you'll like. It's spicy and vanillic mostly with some fresh citrus. Also the tea note is noticeable which gives this a sort of jungle vibe. This is extremely unique and good for the collection! This is a fantastic scent!
All I can smell is the seasoning mix in a pack of instant shrimp ramen.

I thought I would love this based on the notes and the fact I love nutmeg. The one note I was worried about was the benzoin. Just got it today and the benzoin was so sickly sweet I could feel it in my throat. Most of the online reviews played down the sweetness and said it was hardly noticeable and they were Def nicely wrong. Almost made me feel sick. I hate sweet men's fragrances as they smell childish. So from now on anything with vanilla, benzoin or tonka are a no for me.

1 of the best fragrances I ever owned "as a scent profile" .. little sour, tangy, peppery, very unique & different💗 ..nothing beats spicy peppery citrusy fragrances.. think of Terre dHermes EDT and ADG by Armani and this one.

Average performance... the whole experience lasts for 5 hours ..still can be the perfect light cologne after showering/bedtime maybe.

KJ by Kenzo, ADG by Armani, and the dreamer by Versace were my favorite fresh fragrances when I was 15....memories 💙... I recommend buying / blind buying it...YES, I forgive the average performance... 100% worth the try!

This is a really interesting fragrance. On me, it's like they blended all these components and notes to come up with a really musky scent.
This is really warm without being cloying, and spicy without being abrasive or harsh. It is unique in that for a spicy scent it does not rely on pepper.
Jungle is comforting. It's a wonderful blend of wood and spice and gives me the impression of a richer Lalique Encre Noire original with the vetiver dialed back and amber turned up.
Mr. Cresp, most appreciated. Thank you for this beautiful blend that melds with my own scent so smoothly and keeps me relaxed throughout the day. Bravo

Scent is from 98’ and it smells like it! In a good way. This is such a pleasant woody old school fragrance. Will still get you compliments! Edit: scratch everything I said! An hour into this fragrance and that is when it really shines!the lime and citrus and come out to play and smells totally different.
very spicy fragrance, I like it and also can wear it in the summer time

I bought this 2 1/2 years ago. I love the scent. Oily sandalwood with citrus floating over a cinnamon and nutmeg base; nothing bad at all. In fact, it smells great. My original signature scent senior year of high school and college was Obsession After Shave (early 90s). It smelled great, but nothing like today's Obsession. I am always looking for a replacement for that hole in my wardrobe.

Kenzo Jungle would fill that void nicely, but the performance is so lousy. 15 sprays goes nowhere. Whether on skin, clothing, lotion, or hair, doesn't matter. Jungle does not last. I found a seller on ebay selling a sealed bottle date 2011. I paid extra for the older formula and it has terrible performance too.

So, Kenzo Jungle smells sublime. Take the bottle with you. Spray it intermittently all day and you will smell fantastic. This could be a 12 month scent. It is pretty versatile. Just very weak with no longevity.
Scent is a 10/10. Longevity is 1/10. So if you blind buy, be aware of the lack of lasting power of this scent.
The only scent I have that is worse is Pat Zileri Sartoriale. Another beautiful scent that goes poof and is gone.

I love this scent. I don't have the nose to decipher the notes, I'm still in training (lol), but to make it simple for scents for dummies I'd have to say it smells like Oranges/Cinnamon/a lil cumin/and amber (probably the sandalwood).....warm creamy citrus......beautiful scent.

I live in Indonesia, having this one for quite long time and pretty sure the opening smells exactly like food Rendang Padang. I love Nasi Padang, but don't want my body odor smells like Indonesian favorite dish :')

Maybe for western country this would be great.

Oh I pretty sure can smells fresh Gardenia in this base note that I really love after few hours!

Nice smelling fragrance. Sweet spices and a slightly, whispered, roughness in the mid that, keeping with the jungle theme, smells sort of like the canvas of the tent you would pitch. Didnt notice it on card, but on skin it manifests. Sort of a canvas or leather. Maybe it's the wide brimmed hat you're wearing on your trek through the jungle. It's not cumin, as some have suggested. It's got to be an accord formed by other notes. I would guess that the mate note plays a big role in that facet. I am very sensitive to the body odor, sweaty smell of cumin and can detect it a mile away. This stops way short of the unpleasantness of cumin. I like it. It's like the difference between the sweatiness of canvas compared to human body odor.
The bottle is nice too.
But the performance is almost zero. None. Many sprays. Over 15 including clothes. Always a faint skin scent.
I like it, but I don't love it. It does have old school / throwback vibe to it for sure. Very spicy. For younger guys that are used to modern mass appealing fragrances this can be a bit too much.

Man, I love this one..for the smell. The top is free will citrus and tall grass and I guess cinnamon..not heavy on the cinnamon but more on the vetiver. The mid is my favorite part where the cumin comes in and gives it that animal funk but it is not stinky funk. Cumin I do not see listed in the ingredients but I say it is there. It has to be. On dry down the cumin lays back a bit and the woods benzoin and vetiver take over and at that point you have another few hours before its a skin scent and shortly gone from there. But what a ride! I really LOVE the way this frag smells and the journey it takes you on. To me, it is worth having in my collection. Unforgettable and unique. The cap...that is kinda cool and original lol. I suppose you can give it a spray and it is its own test strip? Great bottle.

Long : 4.5/10
Proj : 4.5/10
Sill : 4.5/10
Scent : 8.5/10
Overall : 7/10

Jungle Homme opens with a blast of spice. It smells a little sweaty like cumin to me, so I'm surprised that it is not listed in the top notes. After a few minutes though, it fades...but stays spicy. I definitely get the cinnamon, nutmeg, and cardamom along with some really bright citrus. That spicy citrus floats over a soft, creamy bed of sandalwood and benzoin. That is the best part of this scent, in my opinion.

This was launched in the late nineties and it smells like it. Back then, I think designer fragrances took more risks, in an effort to stand out. I miss that. Years later, Jungle Homme is still amazing...dry, musky, beautiful. So distinctive and memorable, I love this stuff.

J'adore.
Sublime woodsy elegance - yet uplifting, bright, meditative and utterly intoxicating.
Reminds me of an antique Chinese cabinet my Mum has, made from different fragrant woods and even though it's well over a century old, if you leave clothes in the compartments for a few months they emerge imbued with a faint woody fragrance that reminds me of this.

Jungle Homme is very Palo Santo. Palo Santo ("holy wood") gets its name because it was used as ceremonial incense by the Inca and has a relaxed, meditative quality.
The guaiac wood (Palo Santo aka Lignum Vitae is the raw material) is very prominent in Jungle Homme - the star of the show - and lends a distinctive, uplifting presence that for some reason makes me think of velvet. Guaiac has a subtle, slightly camphoraceous aspect that lends a kind of brightness and freshness, yet still anchors the composition.
If I recall rightly, this was the first guaiac fragrance I ever experienced and I was captivated back then and remain so today.
Incidentally, there is a very similar guaiac thing going on in CDG Wonderwood.

Jungle Homme doesn't really evolve much on my skin, it transitions from the opening into a subtly spiced woodsy symphony (starring guaiac wood), tailored and enhanced by the other components, of which facets of cardamom, cinnamon and nutmeg are perhaps most noticeable to my amateur nose, and it is this composite blend that persists through to the dry down.

The bottle I have at present is from 2010, the original version in the purple box with the light green square.
Don't know what the current version is like, but will doubtless find out soon.
Performance is okay, but not stellar, and in Winter KJH lasts around six hours on my currently very dry (but usually oily) skin - really wish longevity were greater.
In the past Jungle Homme did perform much better when my skin was more oily (I hate that term but it's how they categorise my skin type) so I usually extend the lifespan by applying it over an improvised fond de parfum - fractionated coconut oil, almond oil, or white ambergris, which more than doubles its longevity.

As I adore woody fragrances and am partial to Palo Santo as a home fragrance (heating wood chips Japanese style in an electric burner releases the oil without combustion) find this a comforting, relaxing, elegant fragrance that most people seem to really like. Every time I wear this,

Jungle Homme really is an exquisitely beautiful blend of woods and spices - elegant and stylish. This smells niche, quality, classy. Due to the very prominent guaiacol I tend to think of it as CDG Wonderwood's older, wiser, more worldly brother.

I appreciate the presentation of the bottle it’s unique
The juice is spicy but different
Lasts for a good while
It settles down fast so don’t expect anyone noticing your fragrance
A pleasant fragrance but not something I loved

Like everyone here, I blind bought this one. Bought the older formula that comes in the older purple box. Right off the bat, when I sprayed it I was hit with a sense of familiarity that this is something I smelled at the turn of the past millennium. Either someone I knew used to own it or the DNA is similar to the fragrances released at that time. It’s quite pleasant but I’m not crazy about it. Was expecting something warmer/darker with prominent musks but this actually has a lot of brightness from the citruses and vetiver. Don’t regret buying it though, as this is nostalgia in a bottle for me and it wasn’t expensive anyway.

Kenzo Jungle Homme is a cinnamon forward scent full of warm dry spices, touches of light citrus, grassy hay like maté, and some powdered woods. In the dry down it's a big cup of lemon chai tea served sitting on a bed of creamy woods with the vanilla like aroma of benzoin smoldering nearby. One of the most unique spice based fragrances I've experienced. I'm really digging Jungle, perfect for the colder half of the year and could fit in Spring as well. Personally I just wear it whenever but I know a lot of people like to apply seasonal only wears to fragrances. The bottle has a great shape and a random Zebra motif to go along with the Jungle name, even though Zebras live on the grasslands and savannas of Africa and not in jungles. Maybe a Silverback or Leopard would've been a more fitting choice?
ooommm.yesssssss,,,smell like great sexy beautiful teenboy ...

It's a great fragrance, Elegant, Classy, Sophisticated. I blind - bought this hidden gem base on positive comments. I checked reviews on YouTube, Special thanks to : Scent Land and Gents Scents. This perfume has an unusual and a very strange Opening , It smells like pencil shavings but dry down is very wonderful ! It opens up with like warm spicy then dry down is semi sweet woody. It has a unique composition. This is perfect for the spring and fall. The art of bottle design is very beautiful. I love Kenzo Jungle Homme EDT.
Bravo Monsieur Cresp !
Two Thumbs Up.
Rating : 8.5 / 10

This review is for the current formulation. Very disappointed with this fragrance. It didn’t last on my skin at all. After 30 minutes the scent completely disappeared, as if I didn’t spray anything at all. A friend purchased the same fragrance, and had the same problem. Very sad because I love Kenzo Jungle L’Elephant, and was expecting a similar vibe.

the opening can be divisive because it smells like Winners/Marshalls/Homesense but the dry down is amazing. I get a strong woodiness in the beginning although it becomes less prominent in the drydown. good value for money, price means that blind buying shouldn't really be too much of an issue.

This is amazing fragrance! I am really glad i have it in my collection. I agree with the review below, i think is really similar to CdG Wonderwood, in my opinion even better version of it, because is a little more sweet. Anyone should try this if is a fan of Wonderwood.

Blind buy, which I almost never do. And what a surprise. Interesting spicy scent with that odd milky undertone that I realy like. The big surprise is that it really reminds me of Gucci Rush for Men - not the same, but it has a similar vibe to it. Or at least the closest to GRfM that I've smelled. Glad I got it.

Kenzo Jungle Homme
Blind buy. Found it offered on an ebay seller's page. I am not that familiar with Kenzo. One of my favorite models works for them in Paris, so I thought I'd give it a try. Arrived yesterday. I can think of nothing else it smells like. I do get nutmeg, cardamom, pepper, and the guaiac wood. And definitely the lime. But there's something else going on here. Very interesting. A little animalic. And I swear, almost tea. That must be the mate. I love it. May not be for everyone, but if you are looking for something very different, give this juice a try.

Kenzo Jungle Homme is a masterpiece! After hearing about the sad death of Kenzo Takada, I began to look into his fragrances and eventually stumbled upon Kenzo Jungle Homme. As a joke, I describe it to my friends as what a sweaty gorilla would smell like if they smelled good. It almost teleports you into the jungle, but some people have told me I smell like a cinnamon cookie. Not a gourmand fragrance, but I'll take it as a compliment. Longevity and Projection as below average, but nothing can beat the scent for the price (maybe CDNIM but that's a clone). Give this one a shot! It might surprise you:)

This is a nicely layered one. Opening is fresh citric with a nutmeg/cinnamon spicy scent running through it. A really nice combo, and it's in the drydown really nice woodsy, pepper in the background. It's like squishing a lime in an uncleaned elephant cage. Sillage is moderate to a skin scent, longevity is moderate. But the evolution and layering of the scent is just really nice :)

This does indeed smell like Gorilla House At The Zoo (with hay) + a twist of lime, to me. A humid, masculine musk like male pheromones made detectable, but without any sweatiness. However, saying that makes it sound like a stinky beast, whereas I actually find it quite mild and even potentially unisex. Not what I would have thought of if you said "spicy", definitely not dry. I'm not getting any creaminess at all. I was hoping it would be similar to the women's Jungle Elephant but without the vanilla dry down. It is not.

Edit: Oh actually, if I spray a lot more on it becomes less animalistic and more spicy, but not particularly stronger.
RIP Kenzo he just died from covid, the vintage version of this fragrance is amazing spicy woody masculine

No one noticed the similarities, which are huge, with Comme de Garcons Wonderwood?
Very interesting, because I love that CdG.

It's like 80% CdG Wonderwood, but this might actually be a lot better!?
Jungle feels like the grandfather of Wonderwood.
Literally smells a little bit like an old person in a good way.
Wonderwood has more sandalwood, Jungle has more citrus and spices. Both peppery.
I need to stock up since it's way cheaper than CdG.

This is like wood shaving/s, that's what I get. Definitely summer scent for me, maybe perfect as a base for something spicier or more boozy scent. I like the concept of Kenzo with their frags almost minimalist like Jap fashion, personal fave tho is Pour Homme...

Kenzo Jungle is a unique woody scent that seems to be well done but I don't think it's for me.

The scent, especially in the beginning, triggered a specific scent memory for me. It smells like when you're working with wood with a drill or saw and the wood heats up due to friction. I mainly get nutmeg and woody notes, not much more.

I blind bought this and I regret it. This fragrance is bad. I cannot describe it as it is very unique. However, I would say why would anyone want to smell like this? It kind of smells like a woman's product for me strangely. Hmm I hope this grows on me.

I realized the statement I am about to make may make eyes roll...but the performance on my bottle of Jungle is just unacceptable. It's so faint that I honestly cannot even smell it on myself after an hour (and I did NOT under spray...to put it mildly). It's a divine scent. I love everything about this, from the opening to the dry down. 10/10 for the spicy, sensual, beautiful fragrance. But come on Kenzo! Take my experience with a grain of salt if you will, but I have to warn you- save your money and buy something else. Such a shame to water down such a great scent like this.

The original Spicebomb!

A spicy, but still subtle oriental featuring nutmeg, cedar, creamy guaiac wood and sandalwood with added benzoine. Rich, sweet and slightly floral.

Opening with lime - a bold and somewhat surprising move for an oriental - on a note of mate, settling on nutmeg and some sweet, powdery woods. Overall, it's rather linear. Longevity and projection are average, but very fitting for this type of scent.

Although I find it quite different from the last I've tried from the Kenzo line (where most are either aquatic or have an asian "bamboo-feel" to it that are mostly suited for warmer weather), this is a surprisingly nice fragrance that shines in colder temperatures.

This is unisex in my opinion. Has hyper real spices and loads of them, but somehow not overbearing. I also love Jungle elephant - this has a similar feel, just with the sweetness diled down and heaps of wood.

Not getting any citrus unfortunetly, but lots of nutmeg, cinnamon, black pepper and cardamon - basicaly chai spices mixed with wood shavings (not ceder wood though. Also for me, no animalitic notes.

Dont get any of the generic cologne notes that sometimes get in the way of me wearing a "guys" scent - although on a guy this would be very masculine. On women I think this is a sexy oriental with an attitude problem.
⛤⛤⛤⛤

Sexy spicy orange creamsicle.

When I first started wearing it I immediately noticed that "B.O" aroma (maybe an animal/musk note that was causing it?) but didn't mind as it just seemed to fit.

It opens sharp with a ginger/spice/orange top. It goes into the heart and base notes quickly which to me are spicy/warm woods and musk with a little citrus that stays around for a few hours. Silage is around average.

I love wearing it in the summer and during humid days as it seems to amplify the sharpness and sweetness of the citrus and can catch a whiff of something edgy and primal.
Sillage and longevity have been limited. I hate IFRA.

I remember this fragrance being released, but I always like the smell of Jungle Homme but felt it was a bit lightweight. I don't know if it's nostalgia but when I smell it now I get the subtle nuance, Oliver Cresp is wanting to convey. Relaxed, lime opening which is gently spiced with cinnamon, nutmeg and cardamom, melting into a soft sandalwood musk. It smells exotic and is quietly projecting and lasting well too. Truly stunning. Kinda reminds me of lots of things but is unique at the same time. Maybe Gucci Envy a fragrance from a similar time period, maybe a touch of Lalique Homme and Equis? Something about this is just so 90's. I effectively blind bought as I genuinely couldn't remember what Jungle Homme smelled like and I'm over the moon with it. I really like Kenzo as a brand, even the clothes are cool (despite the hefty pricetag) and the playful and let's face it slightly ridiculous design of the flacon needs a place in my wardrobe. I haven't had a Kenzo fragrance since Homme and that was going way back.

The 100 Days Challenge - Day 20:

My first headturner. I remember it exactly. It was midday and i entered into a perfume store here in Montevideo. The air was hot and humid, like in a jungle. I asked the lady who worked there to offer me something special: she had me trying this. I loved it. I reeked like an alpha lion and i loved it. Once i came into my house, my girlfriend at the time stopped eating as i entered the room just to scream how amazingly sexy I smelled. Roaring appeal.


Today's words: Oral fixation.

This one is special for me. Very original fragrance, and hard to deliver in words.. the author gave the only possible name to it - "Jungle".
It comforts me. It's like I'm petting some wild animal - and not feeling dangerous about that, right opposite - feeling "related".. There is also something soft like fur and sweet like vanilla about it.. - not candy-sweet though, rather 'sweet' like reference to person - "he's sweet guy"; and there is no vanilla in ingredients - so I guess my senses pull 'vanilla' as as association of "vanilla sex".
I live in Florida - it's hot and humid here most of the year. Strangely, without being "crisp", this fragrance behaves really well for such weather. I've experimented with fresh and airy "Aqua di..." and Citrus-y types - they all work, of cause, - but that's what became common way to smell round here, so in a way I feel tired of it.. From another hand - applying other interesting "fougere" or "gourmand" types not always finishes well for me: I do sweat (excuse details) and get overwhelmed by heat at moments, and suddenly perfume may turn suffocating.. not this one.. This one harmonizes me with all this heat, I don't feel hunted down by blazing sun and steaming everglades - I feel almost becoming part of it.. this is fascinating.
First time I smelled 'Jungle' in early 2000s. I thought "my gosh, how exotic..." and I was not ready - I wanted to smell "popular" (this fragrance arguably never was and probably never will be "popular").. These days I don't want anymore to be popular, don't want to "stand out and challenge" either.. This is the fragrance that makes me feel free. I never get compliments or remarks on it, but I notice people's perception of me is affected when I wear it.. they like me and do not attack me.. LOL. I wear it on and off for 2 years now.
Anyways.. silage is 'careful'; projection is - 'crouching Tiger/hidden Dragon'; longevity is 'great' on my skin/hair - in 6-8 hours it keeps radiating gently, and next day in shower I suddenly revive it for one more whiff; fragrance itself - 'Unique and Harmonious'.
If you're looking to be a "star of the evening" - I don't think this will "bit competitors". It will stand free and non-intrusive, like wild exotic animal we see on a distance..
My overall rating 10/10.
Thanks.
I need a new bottle

Totally adore this juice! So effortless and special. Totally carefree and uplifting with its exotic woodiness and fresh aromatic character. Year apart from today boring releases, this bears enough originality to stand the test of time (as it does already since 1998). Sometimes these hidden gems are created and then get appreciated by those who seek for individualism apart from the mainstream in designer fragrances. Though Zebras don't live in the Jungle, I still love this juice to bits!

I don't know if this fume falls under the category of missing notes (not listed) or if the right combination of notes gives the effect of another note...To me, this opens with a very clear cumin and lime flurry that is grounded by the richness of a coconut and sandalwood heart/base. It's like indulging in a spiced coconut cream - there is just a hint of cinnamon, cardamom, and mate sprinkled on a creamy, woody (thanks to the clear cedar note) coconut mixed with a dense white muck and airy sandalwood. This is sublime and smells something like abstract art with notes you are familiar with done in a way that is quite difficult to decipher. I am repelled and attracted to it simultaneously - it is very dissonant but madly attractive...such a mad love! It stays fairly linear in it spiced coconut concoction for quite some time but dries off to a very pleasing white musk (and nutmeg?!?) that clings to skin for hours. It's definitely a unique spring/summer scent that can be pulled off in the colder months as well. I also think this is appropriate for all genders as nothing in here screams man. Anyways, I hope you all find a feast for fit for your greatness!

From the reviews I was expecting something that would take some getting used to. That didn't happen. I liked this scent right from first spray. It started off really citrusy, the citrus gave way to some sweet spices before drying to a nice cozy wood. This might be an ignorance is bliss situation. Not being able to pick out individual notes may be saving me from smelling the B.O. or tropical fruit or wet wood notes that I've seen mentioned in other reviews. The bottle is pretty cool too, so add some points for that as well.

Kenzo Jungle is truly what one neophyte would call ¨exotic¨: Sweet and smokey at the same time (cinnamon,benzoin,sandalwood), round up by a heavy measure of tropical wood notes (cedar+guaiac), a tad animalic (pepper,spices): it´s impressive, evocative, lush, and quite sexy. It lives up to its name; not necesarely reminiscent of the jungle itself, but how it feels like to be in a wooden lodge in the evening, in good company while looking at the sun setting beyond the tropical forest, lulled by the sounds of animals; mysterious, exciting, sensual.
It´s interesting to see that such a fragrance was once marketed for the masses (which really shows how the 90´s were more bold tastewise than what we´ve got nowadays). I still remember the impressive TV commercial for the female version "Elephant" back in the day, another interesting and beautiful scent, just a bit sweeter and a tad less woodier.

For those interested in trying it: Jungle always reacted very well for me in any occasion but I would recommend waiting for the drydown to really make up your mind about it; give it time, and remember these kind of fragrances (spicy, aromatic) react differently on each one´s skin. If you pass the tests...welcome to the jungle!

My 2.5 year old daughter says I smell like "Father Kipmis" (her way of saying Father Christmas or Santa Claus or St Nick). She obviously also smells the pine needles and pine trees. Back on point, this is a unique but very odd scent. I'm not a fan.

My gripe is that it is weak. I need at least 10 sprays on body and clothing to get something happening. Admittedly, the big variable between bottles is how much liquid the sprayer delivers per spray. Edited 2018-03-27
I realise now the sprayer on my bottle is delivering a very small quantity with each spray and this is my issue, not its strength.

A blind purchase based on the largely positive views on Fragrantica, but also a desire to try something different. Loving Kenzo Homme and finding a good online offer, I thought what could go wrong?

Before addressing the substance, a distinguishing feature is the course "brush" with an angled cut surmounting the lid - presumably meant to resemble a jungle creature's fur. Textured like a shaving brush and striped like a zebra or a hyena — which are savannah (not jungle) dwellers — this seeming inconsistency and confusion extends to the contents.

The opening is like a semi-ferment of coconut, lime and pineapple - the sort of over-ripe fruit scavenged by the likes of tapirs and warthogs. (I keep getting an image of Pumbaa). Bizarre. Challenging. The effect is like...body odour? Even a primate enclosure at a zoo. It is like someone going unwashed for days then applying a fruity/woody body mist to mask their B.O. This is the first occasion I've had cause to describe the top notes of any perfume as unpleasant.

Even so, a slow transformation over several minutes results in a woody "something". Just not sure exactly what. To be honest, it doesn't redeem itself a whole lot. It's just less unpleasant.

Wearing this on a long-haul flight would be particularly inconsiderate, not to say antisocial. Which begs a load of questions. Primarily, what conceivable occasion could wearing it be appropriate? Would it be worn in the hope of attracting a partner; or should that be mate? If so, which species? And by extension what sex? (I jest of course. At least up to a point I do.)

Quite honestly I'm lost with Jungle. Fair to say it is off-the-scale niche. I'm perplexed by the encounter and astounded by the positive voting on Fragrantica. My experience has earned Jungle the distinction for being amongst the least likeable mens aftershaves that I've tried, and at present I'm not minded to test it again.

Definitely a try before you buy. But, if you know someone called Jane who expresses a predilection for men in a loincloth, this could be for you. Otherwise be warned: you've no one to blame if you're bitten by a tsetse! Unless you purposely choose to smell like a macaque. Or is it a fruit bat? An anteater? Lemur...capybara…sloth...

Does somebody in this jungle have dysentery?

The opening to this is horrible. It really kind of stands out as a disaster among the many fragrances I've tried. A brief flash of lime and cedar turn into a sour, sweaty mash-up of B.O., rotten fruit, and fetid chaos. At first it was mildly revolting--an unpleasant smell of body odor which sometimes occurs when cumin, carraway, or in this case, ambrette seeds are used. I don't like that, but it's tolerable. You see it in Declaration, Rose 31, Carbon, etc. However, it's like the lime note suddenly decayed before my eyes a la time lapse photography and went from fresh, to sour, to overripe, and finally to something completely rotten and putrid. Blending with the ambrette seeds, this made for an awful stench.

Anyway, that all happens in about 5 minutes. The one thing that really impresses me about this, in spite of its questionable opening, is that the ambiance of the fragrance actually reflects a jungle's climate quite realistically. It's humid, almost sweltering, and exudes a damp, dank heat. So I have to give credit to Olivier Cresp for accomplishing this. It's kind of impressive. How many fragrances usually nail their environment dead-on like that? Not a lot.

As it settles in, the lime drifts pretty far to the background and Jungle becomes more of a wood and nutmeg fragrance. It's nice. The woods are soft, creamy, and warm, keeping in tune with the jungle theme. It's that cedar/sandalwood/vetiver blend which sort of smells like all of them and none of them at the same time--an accord that you can pick apart into each component if you wish, but is probably easier left as is--a pleasant "woody" base that does its job well. The nutmeg is spicy and a little sweaty. It's not overpowering. It compliments the woods well, and gives them a spicy character.

At last, everything rests in a soft cushion of benzoin, with its mellow vibration creating a relaxing, tranquil aura. Benzoin has that slightly sweet vanillic smell and it works harmoniously with the woods and nutmeg described earlier.

What a strange fragrance! I started off kind of hating it, and by now I kind of love it. In fact, I'm sort of looking forward to experiencing its awful opening again. Sometimes when you know such a bizarre opening is short-lived, and that what follows is pleasant and good and interesting, it doesn't bother you as much. Harsh openings sometimes even make for the best openings over time.

So would I wear this on a first date? Probably not. But once it settles in Jungle smells good and doesn't really have anything offensive about it. However, it remains interesting. I think you could wear this any time of year, in a casual situation or when you feel like wearing something for yourself. It's too strange to be a formal frag and it's too cool to wear to work. Longevity is excellent, and projection is moderate. If you've ever smelled Burberry London or Pal Zileri's Sartoriale, Jungle's dry down has characteristics of each.

So in the end, Jungle has won me over. I'm still skeptical about its first 5 minutes, but I'll be damned if this fragrance doesn't have character. Cresp nailed the jungle's atmosphere and the fragrance became more and more appealing with each new development.

Kenzo Jungle Homme is a very nice smell. I don't know how the real jungle smells, but there is something intriguing and very animalistic in this fragrance.

Kenzo’s Jungle Homme is that kind of perfume that I am always ready to highly recommend.
At the middle of the last decade it was, for a while, my favorite scent – and I didn’t forget that.
Its quality and my nostalgia, combined, drove me to an undoubtedly simple truth: Jungle Homme it’s a very, very good male perfume.
It is truly aromatic and very persistent – surprisingly strong for a Japanese fragrance, but equal in nerve with his Elephant feminine version. Those who love Azzaro PH or TdH (among others) know it, I suppose.
The simple fact that Kenzo keeps that treasure alive gives me optimism: some good scents will never die, I hope.
In my humble opinion, KJH is a 9+/10 fragrance. In other words, it’s a must.

Kenzo Jungle Homme is just as spicy and bold as its female predecessors. Some member on the forum suggested it to me, and although I cannot remember their name, (my apologies), I am most grateful for their suggestion.

Kenzo Jungle Homme is unisex. The same could be said of Kenzo Jungle L'Elephant. Think of these fragrances as genderless. As you would expect, Kenzo Jungle Homme opens with an array of exotic spices, including cinnamon, pepper, cardamom and nutmeg. There's the slightest hint of citrus in the top notes, however it provides more sweetness than it does freshness.

Underrated this fragrance most certainly is. I'm surprised that Kenzo Jungle Homme is one of the less talked about Kenzo masculines. Perhaps some men consider it a risky choice, a fragrance that packs too much of a punch.

On my skin Kenzo Jungle Homme smells fantastic, perfect for a chilly, overcast day. The drydown is fairly woodsy, with gaiac wood, cedar and sandalwood. Now that I think about it, this fragrance could easily pass as niche. To be more precise, it smells like something M. Micallef would put her name to.

Kenzo Jungle Homme's longevity is excellent, and the sillage strong but not overwhelming. For both sexes, a spicy and unique masterpiece. I highly recommend.

I really wanted to like this one because I'm a fan of the combination of sweet, spciy and woody notes that are used here. But there is a hint of chemical/ammonia that sits in the background on my skin that knocks it down a few notches. Could be the guaiac wood or maybe I just got a bad sample, so I'm not ready to completely write this one off just yet.

I tried it out today for the first time with some other perfumes on both my arms (voyage d'hermes, fahrenheit and jaguar vision). The only 2 standing are the jaguar and kenzo jungle.

This fragrance started out woody on my arm, very woody and stayed that way for some time. I kept sniffing my forearm again and again as it really started to develop around the 3 hour mark, turning sweet and the woods started to disappear but ever so slowly. The appearance of the sweet base was wonderful, not too strong, not too harsh and thankfully not too sweet. A scent that can be worn by anyone above 20 in my opinion, but definitely good with a lively, mannered personality.

I feared there would be a strong synthetic cedar note in here, as is so common these days in "men's" fragrances, but that is not the case. The wood is here is almost transparent, actually (but not in a synthetic way). You know it's there but it's barely noticeable. I agree with those who think this is unisex. The spice is obvious and strong. There is also a powdery quality and it's a little sweet, but just a little, and it's got just enough dynamism to keep it interesting. The citrus is blended in nicely so you don't get a literal smell of a particular fruit, which I generally dislike unless it is soft. Really well done and worth the reasonable prices it is selling for at the moment.

I just love the cinnamon-nutmeg chord in this fragrance. Also Benzoin does a good job in the balance. All those woods are in the base all the time and in the opening, the cardamom note is very comforting. Jungle is Warm and mysterious. It reminds me of that old red oil to polish the furniture, I don't say it resembles it, but remind me of. Hours later, close to the skin, it gets very soft and woody. Jungle gives a very nice experience.
//Update: This one is for fall and surely it will be great for winter and holidays. All those notes just make me feel good. I really like the zebra idea, but maybe Jungle is not the best name. It is a very nice surprise how this change with the weather. If someone first tried Jungle on summer, give it another try... from like to love.
***
Amo el acorde de canela-nuez moscada en esta fragancia. También el benjuí (creo que es la traducción) hace un buen trabajo en el balance. Todas esas maderas están en la base todo el tiempo y en la apertura, la nota de cardamomo es muy confortante. Jungle es misterioso y cálido. Me recuerda a ese viejo aceite rojo para pulir muebles, no digo que huela parecido, pero me lo recuerda. Algunas horas después, cerca de la piel, se vuelve muy suave y amaderado. Jungle te da una muy agradable experiencia.
Actualización: Esta es para otoño y seguro será genial en invierno y las fiestas. Todas esas notas me han hecho sentir bien. Me gusta mucho el concepto de la cebra, pero quizá Jungle no sea el mejor nombre. Muy agradable sorpresa cómo cambió con el clima. Si alguien la probó por primera vez en verano, dele otra oportunidad. Pasó de gustar a encantarme.

However very good.....exspecially for the fall and the winter time.

I have received a mini of this cologne from a friend of mine and I decided to fill up a little spray recipient in order to make a test on my skin.

I’ve never been a huge fan of Kenzo’s colognes, except for Kenzo Air (which I have in my personal collection), L’Eau Par Kenzo Indigo and Woody (which I liked a lot when I tried it), but I have noticed that the male fragrances are starting to improve, leaving aside the DNA of Kenzo Homme.

Well, Kenzo Jungle is another one that I liked! It is sweet in the right way, the kind of smell I use to love.
When I first applied on my skin, I thought: “uhm…too similar to Black Walnut”. But this feeling ended within three minutes.

This one evolves very fast and makes the cardamom and the amber notes more prominent, well blended with the nutmeg. I think that the real difference is the amber in the heart notes, instead of the base notes as usual.
After that what remains on my skin is a “soft gourmand” smell, which is something typical in scents that bring benzoin in its notes. I didn’t feel the vetiver; only the benzoin and the sandalwood.

Kenzo Jungle remains all day long, but the projection is weak. The fragrance is very good and comfortable, especially in cold weather to complete the whole scene. I give 8.5 from 10!

I admit: I'm a woman and bought it for myself.
But I was a good woman and shared my miniature with my husband :D
And you know what? The fragrance started sour on me and on him the start is wild and sweet. It's the difference between woman's and man's skin, I guess.
The fragrance smells very sexy on him. Meow! :D

What can I say - this is one of THOSE perfumes. When I smell it I'm instantly in Paris, in an atelier of a painter who is out of this world sexy, wearing an unbuttoned white shirt with sleeves tucked up, barefoot. It is late afternoon, golden sunlight is coming in through the window, the air is ambery and thick of smell of terpentine and dry, balsamic wood of the floorboards. We have painted, drank mojito and smoked all afternoon. He is so atractive with those unshaven cheeks...

(Unfortunately, it is over too soon. The lasting power is not the best here...to be precise, it lasts long, but the drydown gets fainter and fainter in time)

PS: OK, I know it's totally tacky - Paris, painter, like a Harlequin book... But you can't really help the images in your head when they appear, and this is exactly the one... But the painter IS a drunkard who doesn't have a shower tube in his atelier, if you like it better like this ;)
Love this scent, bought it in Tahiti and yes deserves a better bottle and re release..Nothing else smells like this, could have better sillage though..

Kenzo Jungle Homme.
Well, it is sweet and pleasant, makes a statement but not much.
While not particularly complex it has a good character and that alone won't let you write anything negative about it.
When you smell it, you want to wear it.
When you see it on the shelf you just don't go for it.

It deserves a better bottle and some sort of excitement :)

بوی دارچین و لیمو
شما را یاد عطاری ها میاندازد من که از بوش لذت میبرم
البته وامش زیاد بالا نیست و پخش بوی متوسطی دارد که این نکته ربط مستقیمی به فصل مصرف و پوست استفاده کننده نیز دارد
از آمبولانژ و شیشه آن به شخصه زیاد خوشم نیامده و در حد و اندازه خود آن رایحه نیست و طراحی ضعیفی دارد اگر آمبولانژش خوب و زیبا بود استقبالش مسلما بیشتر میشد

I like it and it can be worn by women too :)
A little sour in the beginning and spicy. Also smoky, then woody-spicy.
It brings man's sperm to my mind, I can't stop the thought, it really has sthg like this in itself ;) and I see an exotic man living in a jungle, full of life, strength and vitality when I sniff the smell ;)

This perfume is imagine of savana and freedom runner.
Essence matè, lime,ambrette is mix very surprising and extraordinary.One drop of perfume equal to 3 coffee.
Turbosensational.
Highly recommended
aroma amaderado-oriental creo que es un poco insultante para las demás personas que te rodean así es que a tener cuidado con las aplicaciones ..no mas de 3.

This is great! Oak moss, baby! Love it, spices on woods. I can see the jungle inspiration with the warmth and adventure, imagine sitting with a silverback gorilla and a jaguar runs past to take down a sloth, then you join in eating the sloths guts... before the jaguar kills you and eats you.
It has great silage and staying power too.
The perfume, not the jaguar

J'ai vécu une bellle découverte et histoire avec ce parfum... Je l'ai découvert par hasard dans une petite aprfumerie au centre d'Alger il y a quelques semaines de cela et depuis il est devenu mon parfum préféré. Au début, les premières sensations, on ressent que c'est un parfum fort... Mais juste si on prend un peu de temps, on remarque qu'il est rempli de subtilité et de douceurs. C'est un parfum de caractère mais qui révèle un côté sensuel très développé. Sincèrement Kenzo Jungle pour homme représente l'homme à la fois classique réservé et contemporain. . Je le trouve vraiment intriguant et on peut le distinguer des autres. C'est un parfum qu'on reconnait parmi les autres tellement il a du caractère et qu'il possède sa propre signature. Je remercie Kenzo pour cette merveille, parce qu'avec ce parfum on se sent toujours plus jeunes et plus classique.
Bouktache Reda

this fragrance works well with my skin chemistry!i totally love it!

Starts with fresh citruses, then it turns to smooth warm spices. bliss...

Woody-Spicy? I think SPICY-ORIENTAL!!!

Yes, spray it on your pulse points, and then spend 2 hours in a traditional eastern spicery.
Maybe after that you feel walking through the jungle after rain.

It begins very strongly and you can’t do anything but watching the Jungle show.

Very impressive …

وای .. این کنزو جنگل گورخره منو کشته
یه عطر تند تند شدید چوبی عدویه ای تند و شلوغ پلوغ و عالی
اصلاً وقتی این عطر رو بزنین انگار دیگه هیچ کاری نمیتونین انجام بدین بجز اینکه بشینین و نمایش جنگل تماشا کنین

Kenzo jungle is a great fagrance with excellent silage and longevity.
It is warm, dark and woody fragrance. It smells like a tree trunk. I absolutely love this fragrance.
It opens with bright spicy notes and dries down gradually into smooth woody musky notes. Perfect for chilly nights.
Highly complimented.
I give it 8.5 out of 10

this is one of my fave among the onther kenzo's and another brand,,
very complicated aroma..
its warm, fresh, imagination about adventures of freedom..
just like "vertigo" has described it,,
last the whole day,
have a try!!

Its warm scent cause people smell deeply and enjoy!
Love it
very good for winter

This is very dry-wood scent. Sweetened by nutmeg which exists from start to end.
Gets u felt like as if u were in very hot african savannas.
very very nice, warm sensual smell...............smell of the earth

Despite all the extremely good reviews, which took me to this, and are object of my consideration, it has to be one of the most disturbing, disgusting and awful openings I have ever smelled in my entire life, in such a way that I can not imagine anyone over applying it, unless he wants to scare away everybody, and attract the wrong birds. I mean, it may smell things of a jungle, but unfortunately someone could detect remainders left by animals too. My first reaction was in this way: YUUUUUUUUUCK!!!!

I think I know what "vdxl" wanted to say when he wrote "it may smell 'dirty' and not in good way" in the summer days, and about "apply it correctly".

Well, when the all thing is stabilized, it smells better. I read in another forum someone saying that the scent remembered him "pine and cedar trees at Christmas time", and at least twice I had this impression too. Not bad. During the drydown I get the nutmeg. Nothing bad too. I wish I could always get specially the nutmeg!

The orientation is the same: apply it correctly! But as the scent still looks temperamental to me (or I just didn't get the right point yet), for now I don't think is totally safe leave home wearing it.

A very nice oriental fragrance that if you overdose it cannot be so pleasant. I mean apply it correctly and you will smell great: it is sweet, modern, earthy. It is likely you will avoid this oriental in the summer days, as it may smell "dirty" and not in a good way. I like some oriental fragrances in the summer, but not this one.

This is currently my *favorite* scent. It has such an original flavor with great staying power. This starts with heavy green smells of bergamot and citrus. That fades after a few minutes and develops a softer, but masculine woody vanilla. This is a very sexual and alive scent, almost like I should be running through the jungle in a Duran Duran video.

This is another spicy-oriental that I personally enjoy v.v. much, even if I have my chill moments (especially now in winter time) when I like to wear most GivenchyPH & Dreamer.
Kenzo Jungle starts harsh with fresh (green lime) & floral (maté) & honey like notes, rushing into a sweet (nutmeg)-peppery-spicy oriental heart, drying on the skin with a sweet-spicy (nutmeg, sandalwood, guaiacwood) but also greeny (vetiver) & bitter-tea combo...very nice indeed. Also good lasting power & great sillage in the first 2 hrs...my rank: 9/10. ☣☣☣☣☣
Lime, soft wood, a touch of musk. This is very nice, very delicious.
it is not for the every day , but it is one of the best fragrances for date or for the night
i just love it..

Very pleasant woody gentleman smell with a city vibe and specialty feeling. Yes you stand out - not a typical mainstream smell. Not cloned yet ( as far as I'm aware) I wanted to refill my stock but wasn't able to find it anywhere.

Performance: 7-9 hours
Sillage: Arms length
For whom: Gentlemen >35

My background: I only write reviews about scents I have worn already (until the bottle is finished or given away) or are in current use. I'm a Gentlemen - middle aged - predominantly in an executive office environment wearing suits and representing with many official gatherings.
I love Kenzo homme 1991 version, but this version is so woody and even hard for my nose...I could not have it on my self so I gave it away.

The one that got me into fragrances. It was sharp, refreshing, challenging. The best thing young me had ever tried. If they rereleased it I'd buy it again and again and again. Closest I've found is Heliaca by Le Couvent Maison and I highly recommend checking it out.
Got a bottle for sale on Mercari only $72

This fragrance brought me back so many memories of 2007, Tokyo By Kenzo was my first ever fragrance my father bought for me, I’ve used this in my primary school years and garnered plenty of attention with this, everyone loved the fresh yet warm spicy scent of it as it projects the whole classroom (i remember getting scolded by my classteacher whom was scent sensitive for this)

I also love how this fragrance portrays tokyo vibes of 2007 in the international lens, i believe this would be a great fragrance to wear for a fun memorable night, strolling the streets of elite tokyo (preferrably Ginza/Chiyoda) for a dinner in the posh contemporary restaurants & nightclubs of Tokyo
I have a 90ml/100ml for sale. Super rare I know but I'll be cheaper than eBay

A very nice masculine fragrance, associated with a lot of memories on my side, and which has unfortunately been withdrawn from the market. A very striking scent, since at least ten years after I last smelled it, I still remember its nutmeg, pink pepper and citrus scent wonderfully, at once slightly sweet, damp and spicy/pungent. I'd love to hear any recommendations for something similar!
Amazing! From a spicy bang via freshness to a distinguished scent at dryndown. Anyone has a good alternative for the day my bottles are empty? Why did they stop making this?

I had the pleasure of using it in 2009. It is one of those fragances that gets etched into your memory, and is impossible to forget. The waft of the sillage when you wear this perfume is a total head turner that entraps to those who smell it.
It's the kind of perfume that I would buy hands down immediately if i could get my hands on it.

This has been one of my favorite fragrances for a few years now. I think it's a really mild but sophisticated scent. I wish it wasn't discontinued. What I smell most is the citrus plus the hint of spices. The ginger gives it a pepperiness that feels a little green at the same time. It's clean, unoffensive, subtle and yet also noticeable. This was a go to for wearing to work for me. Unlike a lot of other citrus heavy fragrances, I don't see this restricted to warm weather. It's quite versatile. Like other Kenzo fragrances, it's a bit avant-garde in the men's fragrance game and unique, which I appreciate.

I think this is a wonderful fragrance for spring through fall seasons. Unique and not like everyone else wearing Invictus, Dior Sauvage or Bulgari. Dare I say, this reminds me of a much lighter Creed Aventus (minus the birch, vanilla and black currant). It's basically linear, as you get this uplifting, light citrus and woody scent throughout. The performance is average, so it's not overbearing and it's well suited for busy places (as preferred in Tokyo, where I live). Getting harder to find.

This one brings back so many nostalgic memories. I bought my first bottle in the summer of 2007 after graduating from high school. My purchase was based on the marketing campaign, and my love for all things Tokyo. I loved everything about this fragrance. The spicy/citrus and the beautiful woody drydown were so nice. I had my bottle until my first year of college. The best part about wearing something different at the time (I live in Alabama) were the compliments. I stood out from a crowd of ADG and A&F Fierce. I wish this were a scent that hadn't been discontinued.

What a beautiful scent. I only received this early today but it is already one of my favourites, I’m not being rash either just because it’s new to me. It’s a soft spicy woody scent predominantly, it is rather dry but the composition is very smooth and well rounded. I don’t find any of the notes dominate the fragrance, the spices are calm and balanced, not loud and harsh. You do pick up fresh ginger root on the opening. Then the fragrance comes through like tea & spices, with the woody notes being the base of the scent. It’s actually pretty unique, without being ‘out there’ or unusual either. Just lovely and fairly simple. I think it shares something with Tea Tonique by Miller Harris, though I’m not saying they are the same. It certainly isn’t an everlasting nuclear fragrance... but it isn’t supposed to be, it’s not that kind of fragrance.

Tokyo is composed of a dry, woodsy aroma—reflected by a thin chain of peppery sweetness. The style is certainly going for the traditional Japanese masculinity here. The elements are bold and slightly stingy—very dry and brooding. The fragrance is like a contemporary of Acqua di Parma Colonia Intensa if I could describe it in one shot.

In my initial impression, I wanted to say, "It smells like—the coolest m*therf*cker in city of Tokyo!". It is stylish and unique—and compels you with those qualities.

It is also very linear though—and something most would probably mistakenly describe as 'synthetic'—but is much better described as being 'a touch under-blended'.

Following the stereotype of Japanese humbleness—naturalist or minimalist—it is easily a perfect execution of that style. If you're a simple man, you will be certainly delighted by this.

However, Tokyo is a city of big money and fine tastes. So I hate to not think there is some far greater, more sophisticated, privateer formula beyond this veil.

I have to agree with those who said this is a strong 'paper fragrance'. Not sure if we can blame freshness or not (lots of natural ingredients), but performance is sub-par, and I can't seem to get all the notes together except on paper. It certainly is much brighter and sweeter at least.

Still, I do enjoy it for its masculine qualities, and it continues to grow on me more and more over time. Don't expect to get more than you have to give. Very true to Tokyo itself.
Huge recommendation for all "paper based fragnance" lovers
Fantastic perfume, named after a fantastic city. Kudos to Kenzo for a wonderful fragrance.

The scent is perfectly balanced between citrus, spicy, aromatic and woody notes. It's actually quite original and exciting in a bit of a synesthesia -kind of way: I truly get the neon colored theme that is on the bottle. Very, very good.

However, the performance and longevity are poor. I've sprayed 4-6 times and no-one else seems to notice anything special and I don't get anything at all after 2-3 hours.

This is actually a great scent for the days you can't decide what to wear. After a few hours you can spray on something else. And that's not taking anything away from the enjoyment of Kenzo Tokyo. Very good, but short-lived.

This is interesting. It was unexpectedly spicy and pungent in the beginning - in a good way! Like a blend of freshly sliced ginger and peppers. The green tea notes shine through soon after, and slowly develop into a fresh citrusy woody drydown.

This is pretty different from most of the fragrances out there that I've smelled. Not bad! Lacking in performance though.

Tokyo by Kenzo is one of the most awesome 21st century fragrances! It offers 6 to 7-hour longevity and sports moderate to high projection and sillage. It's a delicious, masculine blend of citrus, wood, spices, and green tea.

If you like EDTs in the same vein as Gucci Rush, Quorum Silver, and (even) Fahrenheit Absolute, then Tokyo by Kenzo is for you. It's, in my opinion, a safe blind buy.

Here's my rating:

Fragrance: 9/10
Longevity: 7/10
Projection: 7/10
Sillage: 8/10
Value for Money: 10/10
Total score: 8.2/10

Me as a Kdnzo lover was so so sorry to ever used this one..

Big big NoNo from.me

Sentence Summary:

This is an unusual scent, it reminds me of the smell of a neon-lit backstreet alley from the future, where the air vents pump out a mixture of smells from clubs, pubs and restaurants.
This is what the world of Blade Runner smells like.

Overall rating 7/10

My new addition to my collection. I am quite pleased. I read somewhere that this scent is to be compared to Kenzo Jungle Lelephant. I totally agree, just a weaker version.
I can still smell this though after 6hrs.

This scent was great if not traditionally nontraditional; a spicy "Dior Homme Sport and Gucci Pour Homme II," as one YouTube reviewer put it six years ago, could be bad!? On average the performance is "professionally acceptable," by which I mean its longevity is average but its projection/sillage is close -- a beautifully decent all-purpose fresh and clean fragrance w/some spice (inoffensive i think in an office-environment) scent for the adult man. Note the decent grade it gets here on Fragrantica. I have the cheap but cool-looking 100 ml. bottle plus the body wash, hair gel, and spray as well as roll-on deodorants so as to (necessarily) fully immerse myself in this, literally and figuratively, making a day of it on the occasions when I wear it. It carries a very natural, engaged and engaging, mature but approachable, positive vibe.

Citrus and ginger give it some freshness; pink pepper, spices and green tea thicken it up. Woods provide a nice base for all of this to sit on. Tokyo opens a little bright but quickly smooths out becoming creamier.

Sillage and projection are probably the softest in my collection. Even with an unprecedented (for me) five sprays I get a weak four hours of longevity. I'd say this one is "masculine" but would not smell strange on a woman. Work safe, inoffensive, not bold or sexy. Bottle and sprayer are both good Kenzo quality. The notes create a fresh, modern blend that is more youthful but I think any age can wear this year-round. Tokyo is interesteing; different from most modern colognes but not innovative or particularly exciting. Pretty inexpensive but even taking this into account I'm not sure it's worth it.

This perfume is suitable for use at night in cold weather, both during the winter or during the rainy season. Wearing perfume on the rainy season in the night will add you to the impression of romanticism and make you feel warm.

One of my recent blind buys, and I normally don't get disappointed by Kenzo; this Tokio fragrance is nice so far, first time wearing it. I probably won't by it again or restock as I've done with Kenzo Power, but I don't regret I bought this one.

This is a fragrance I always forget I have, but am pleasantly surprised when I rediscover it. That is not to call it nondescript - rather, I would say its implementation of a prominent combination of pink pepper and green tea (at least for me) makes for a rather interesting take on a spicy men's fragrance. For lack of better terms, this fragrance is very "Seattle" - it always seems to come alive for me when I'm in the city on a rainy day. It's soft, though, and that's really where I land on "like" as opposed to "love." It was a complete blind buy for me, and I would say that's safe to do. If you're intrigued by the notes like I was - I always tend to gravitate towards scents with pink pepper, and this is no exception - then give it a whirl. These days, it certainly won't cost you all that much to try.

Editing to say that, since writing this review, I have made an effort to wear it more. I have fallen in love with this interesting spicy fragrance all the more now! Still have problems with performance and sillage - have to spray quite a bit for it to be noticeable - but when I get it on my clothes, it's such a nice scent that lasts for days. Still love you after all of these years, Kenzo!

I love my spicy Tokyo by Kenzo; I wear it mostly during the daytime (to work) where it lasts a few hours before losing some of the original scent. The bottle is perfect for travel (no lids / sprayers to fall off) and non offensive enough to wear on a plane or to the theatre. Just the ticket; different to what the drones are wearing but still very warm and comforting.

I left so many perfumes behind to be reviewed and probably I´ll never gonna do it. But I´m always coming back to some old fellows, and I´m in the mood for Kenzo these days. If I could put two favourites Kenzo scents in my top list they would be Kenzo Homme and Kenzo Tokyo. The only problem with Tokyo? It looses its spicies along the way and finishes creamy. Just that. I don't know if there is an updated edition of the book, but Tania Sanchez in the Perfumes The Guide co-written with Luca Turin I have says that spray Tokyo on clothes wouldn't be a good idea since it amplifies some aspects of the scent. Since what it amplifies is just what I enjoy the most (spicies) I couldn't desagree more, and in fact it remains less creamy on clothes, and I´m tempted to always spray a bit on clothes. I never tried Vintage and others Kenzo scents, but I know Power and it's a fine floral for men. That Kenzo Power, but specially Kenzo Homme and Kenzo Tokyo, made the name of the brand to me.

You prepare yourself for the big meeting...it will start in just a few minutes. You are surrounded by the hustle and bustle of meaningless motions, everything feels tight. Tight suits, tight ties, tight glances, tight smiles...you wish there was a way to depart, even for a moment. You inhale deeply and close your eyes...You awaken in the center of an immense cedar forest, lost from all of civilization. The heat of the rising sun gently warms the earth and grass around you - the lemon yellow rays creep steadily toward you. The wind sweeps through these gentle giants carrying their peppered ponderings and a clear rush of calming coolness. Everything else fades away - you are one with the earth and the wind, with nature and the sun. Your skin soaks in the infinite beauty of nature in solitude; you are renewed and invigorated. Your consciousness trickles back into reality - the meeting has begun yet you feel nothing but resolution. Your body still tingling from the kiss of cedar and lemon, pepper and cool wind, and the warmth of nature at peace. You are ready for war.

Day 86 - White noise
Listening to: The Gathering - My Electricity

Notes: This was one of my first fragrances, ever. It spurred my love of peppered woods and the soft touch of centering nutmeg. The description states this fume is of deep darkness - I experience the exact opposite! I am elated in the presence of this simple and beautiful fume. It is undoubtedly synthetic, but there is something serene in its presentation. It opens with an invigorating blend of pink pepper and lemons...one sniff puts a smile on my face and eases my nerves ever so slightly. I cannot really sense ginger in here (it usually tingles on the skin) but it could lend to the brightness of the opening. The core of this fume is a wonderful interpretation of cedar - powerful yet peaceful. There is the slightest hint of a warming nutmeg and the rush of a cool breeze from deep within the fume...it stays a slightly smoky and peppery cedar and warm nutmeg for 6 to 8 hours (I don't get how people say this disappears in a few hours...I finished my original bottle from 2008 and the replacement from 2013 is the same). It does quiet significantly around 5 or 6 hours, but it maintains the presence of spiced wood and musk until the 10 hour mark. Ultimately, this is a subtle yet powerful representation of the wonder of cedar and the strength of nature...a delight for all to experience!
I adore kenzo Tokyo. It feels natural and gentle. Along with kenzo power and kenzo boisee - this trio is a favourite and I wear them with much pleasure.

LOVE...LOVE it !!!
Just got it today. How did I miss this gem???
Green scents are very tricky for me..but this one and I are getting along just fine !!! U see the resemblance to Visit..but I get more "powder" from Visit. I also feel a touch of Declaration d'un Soir.....???
Should rather be called Cacophony by Kenzo.

I've been flirting with Kenzo Tokyo for a while. Not entirey sure if I should buy it or not.
Well, I decided to give it a try.
The bottle sends a strong message of color, energy and movement. while the name Tokyo add even more dynamism and energy.
What was I expecting? Not sure, but I guess something to blow my mind, to think "this is the fragrance that I was waiting to appear in my life!"
But to be sincere, I'm not blown away by Kenzo Tokyo. It's a nice fragrance, fresh, green and spicy. But it doesn't go beyond that. It feels like a cologne with more staying power.
It has the citrus opening, full of zing and happiness, the calm and wet green and in the end a quiet spiciness that is paired with the cedar.
Groundbreaking? Perhaps not.
But it's a safe scent. Clean, fresh and safely neutral.
Perfect mix of citrus and spicies.It is my signature scent.Above average longetivity and mediocore sillage.

Fresh, light and citrusy. Sillage and longevity strong. Has a sweet undertone. Initial spray sparkles with ginger and as it dries down the lemon and spices are noticeable. Very pleasant. I wish the ginger was stronger and longer, because as it wanes, the exotic charisma of this scent fades to something familiar and not as special.

Tokyo Kenzo is a quite cool scent. It's modern and I think focused on young people. It's appropriate for many occasions. For me it's every day fragrance but I can imagine someone wearing it for a more formal occasion. It's woody in a very pleasant way. Many woody fragrances have this "grandpa" vibe which I can't stand. This one is really really cool and pleasant. The scent has many leyers and it is really aromatic. You feel like you're having a SPA treatment wearing it.

The only thing which is not good about this fragrance is this citrusy note wich is somewhat too sour. It makes it almost the opposite of fresh. Like an old lemon peel lying somhere in the room. This note almost disappears after a while so it feels unnecessary.
It's got a very special cool fragrance with a big twist of peppery spice! It's absolutely fresh and modern as well.
